AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of a part two storey and part single storey detached dwellinghouse and a detached single storey Outbuilding/Pavilion, with associated landscaping works.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:How the proposed development will be built;Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);The procedure for loading/unloading materials;The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;Temporary site access;Signing system for works traffic;Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;The location of all ancillary site buildings;The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;Wheel washing equipment;The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andThe method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phases.Deliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because: the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the in the south or west elevations of the dwelling unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with: 'Impact Assessment & Method Statement' ref 010458 authored by Ivan Button and dated 5th December 2019; 'Arboricultural Method Statement' rev 1; and 'Tree Protection Plan' rev 2. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cycle parking facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a channel drain shall be installed on the access adjacent to the public footway, in accordance with details which have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to occupation details of the proposed species related to the living wall(s) and their associated irrigation systems and maintenance shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.  The approved works shall be carried out in the first planting season following the completion of the development.  Any planting which within a period of five years from the completion of the development die, are removed, or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species.  All living roofs shall be permanently retained for that purpose only and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To ensure that these works are properly implemented and maintained and in the interest of visual amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a detached dwelling within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Local Area of Special Charater.Six neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.RBK Neighbourhood Engineer - No objectionsThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development and the impact on the wider area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy DM12 is clear that the Council will: 'ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area' and preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design.Officer Comment: The proposed material, design and height of the wall would be similar to the adjacent property and also the existing brickwork on the opposite side of the road. The proposed development would be in keeping with the character and appearance of the area and would not have an adverse impact on the setting of the nearby Grade II* listed Coombe Conduit House to the north-west given that the proposed development would be in keeping with neighbouring development.The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy CS7 of the Core Strategy (Managing Vehicle Use) sets out that the Council will - part d - manage on and off-street parking provision to promote sustainability and residential amenity and smooth traffic flow.The NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree.As noted above, the Highways and Transport department were consulted and have not raised any objection to the proposed development.  No issues have been identified in relation to highway safety.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Site DescriptionThe application concerns the Guildhall, a Grade II Listed Building which currently functions as a public service building for the Council. The building also lies within the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and a designated area of archaeological significance. ProposalRemedial works to Portland stonework cladding and balcony to front of Guildhall and the installation of a stainless steel and toughened glass balustrade.Consultation Kingston Conservation Area Advisory Committee (KCAAC): No objection - these works are long overdueHistoric England: No comments to makeAssessmentThe listing description for the Guildhall is as follows:"1934-5. Maurice Webb. Neo Georgian red brick building with Portland stone dressings and tiled roof. Semi-circular plan. Three storeys with square headed twelve paned windows. Horizontally rusticated stone base. Stone band above first floor. To centre of semi-circular elevation a massive square tower with a low octagonal spire and fluted corner pinnacles. Central entrance in base, of tower. Two storey, round headed window above set in open pedimented stone niche with simplified Corinthian columns rising from corbelled balcony. Pictorial references to the Thames displayed upon keystone inside niche, corbels, capitals and on the iron gates. Crest of Kingston set further up the tower. Marble lined circular entrance hall. Central staircase with original opaque glass semi-spherical lamps. Original wall and hanging lights in south west, council chamber, also of opaque glass with bronze trimming."It is noted that a separate Listed Building Consent application has also been submitted for determination (ref: 20/02945/LBC). The proposed remedial works are as follows:- Remove defective Portland stonework from front balcony and entrance canopy. Clean off all stone and fixings to expose the steelwork.- Clean off all rust from steelwork. Apply coat of rust inhibiting primer and allow to cure.- Template the areas required to receive new stone cladding. Source new Portland Stone to match the existing. Stone mason to install and adapt to suit the required fixings back to the steelwork and to match the details of the original stonework.The balcony deck would be coated in a waterproof membrane to prevent water seeping through the stone deck and affecting the steel structure and would be Pebble Grey in colour to be in keeping with the existing colour. A small hole would be drilled through the balcony deck to allow the insertion of a 50mm internal drainage pipe which would be boxed in within the building. The existing balcony does not have any surface water drainage which may have contributed to the damage to the stone work.To address safety concerns, a permanent handrail and glass balustrade is proposed to be installed. The balustrade would comprise a stainless steel supporting frame and 14mm thick toughened glass. The new stainless steel posts would be resin fixed to the face of the balcony wall meaning that the balustrade could be removed at a later date with little impact to the building itself.The proposed remedial works would replace the existing damaged stonework with stone of a matching appearance and would treat the existing steelwork so as to minimise the risk of any future water damage to the building. The proposed waterproof membrane would be of a similar appearance to the existing roof material to be replaced and the internal drain of approximately 50mm in diameter would fall below to the Plant Roof underneath and would therefore not be visible within the street scene.The proposed balustrade would be of a contemporary appearance, however, it would be relatively limited in scale at a maximum height of approximately 900mm above the balcony deck, approximately 350mm above the balcony wall and approximately 195mm above the central balcony crest. It is further noted that the existing ground floor main entrance disabled access arrangement incorporates a stainless steel and toughened glass screen.ConclusionOverall, it is considered that the proposed remedial works and balustrade would preserve the significance of the listed building, its setting and would restore the elements of its special architectural and historic interest at the main entrance which have been degraded through time. The proposed works would preserve and enhance the significance of the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area by restoring the damaged stonework to a high standard. Accordingly, it is recommended that planning permission be granted subject to planning conditions.

The building also lies within the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and a designated area of archaeological significance. ProposalRemedial works to Portland stonework cladding and balcony to front of Guildhall and the installation of a stainless steel and toughened glass balustrade.Consultation Kingston Conservation Area Advisory Committee (KCAAC): No objection - these works are long overdueHistoric England: No comments to makeAssessmentThe listing description for the Guildhall is as follows:"1934-5. The balustrade would comprise a stainless steel supporting frame and 14mm thick toughened glass. The applicant is advised that  he/she must fulfil his/her duties under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended) and the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 (as amended) in respect of the Peregrine Falcon nesting site on the roof of the tower building, and include any necessary  mitigation measures as previously identified in the College's Peregrine Falcon Advisory Report, prepared by Lazard Landscape Design and Ecology.

The application property is a two-storey detached dwelling located on the eastern side of Bowness Crescent, which is a well-established residential area. The property has a single storey flat roof extension to the side, which does not appear to be an original feature of the property. The side boundary of the property to the north adjoins the large rear gardens of Nos. 2-6 Windermere Road; and the host property has a long rear garden with a depth of approximately 28 metres. The property is not listed nor is it within a conservation area, and there are no other historic assets in the vicinity. The property is located within Flood Risk Zone 1, and so at a low risk of flooding. It is also located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. 10 neighbouring properties were notified of the application and no responses were received following the consultation period. The planning history relevant to this application is:90/0594/FUL - Erection of single storey side extension incorporating garage - approved May 1990The key areas of assessment are:- The impact upon the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact upon residential amenity.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The application property comprises a single-storey extension to the side of the property that has a flat roof finish. The proposal would add a pitch to the roof of the existing extension which would continue and integrate with the proposed rear extension. This is considered to be an appropriate addition to the property. The proposed extension would be of a scale appropriate to the original property and would not unduly dominate its resultant appearance. Appropriate materials would also be used to ensure an acceptable appearance. As the proposal would have the appearance of a domestic extension that is in scale with the original property, it is considered that there would not be an adverse effect on the character and appearance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character and the general streetscene. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Although the proposed extension would be adjacent to the boundary with No. 4 Windermere Road, it is considered that there would not be any adverse impact upon the amenity of these neighbours. The neighbour has an extensive rear garden and the residents would be able to enjoy their amenity space without any undue sense of overbearing or dominance from the extension. There is a good separation distance to the neighbour at No. 16 Bowness Crescent and so an acceptable relationship would be maintained. Whilst the extension would increase the footprint of the property, and so reduce its private amenity space, ample space would remain so that the amenity of the residents would not be compromised. The proposed extension would be in scale with the host property and would not have an adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the area or the wider Strategic Area of Special Character. The residential amenity of the occupants of the property and their neighbours would not be compromised as a result of the development.  In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises an end of terrace building in mixed use with commercial at ground floor and residential above. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Impact on Highway safety.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is appropriate for a commercial premises and it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  A condition to control the level of illuminance is proposed. It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Seven neighbouring propoerties have been notified and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application property is a two-storey, semi-detached property located on the north side of Northcote Road, which is a well-established residential area. The property has an 'L' shaped footprint with a single storey monopitch extension, which does not appear to be an original feature of the property. The adjoining property has a similar footprint that also includes a single storey addition. A shared passageway provides separation distance from the neighbouring property at No. 86, which has a conservatory added to the rear. The property is not listed, nor is it within a conservation area and there are no other historic assets in the vicinity. The site is located within Flood Risk Zone 1, as defined by the Environment Agency, and is therefore at a low risk of flooding.2 neighbouring properties were notified of the application and no responses were received following the consultation period. There is no planning history relevant to this application.The key areas of assessment are:- The impact upon the character and appearance of the area; and- The impact upon residential amenity.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal would involve the loss of the single storey rear addition to the property, though as this is not an original feature of the property and is not considered as having any significant architectural merit, there is no objection to its loss. A single storey side/rear extension with a first floor infill is proposed and these would be in keeping with the scale and character of the original property. The main entrance to the property is via the side elevation where a canopy above the door is proposed. This would be a modest addition to the property and not have any adverse visual impact. The proposal also includes an infill extension at first floor level with the introduction of a hipped roof. Whislt this would result in the squaring off of the appearance of the property it would not adversely affect its original appearance. The works to the rear of the property would not be readily visible from any public viewpoint and it is considered that the development as a whole would not have any adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed development would increase the footprint of the property and thereby reduce the amount of private amenity space at the rear. However, it is considered that ample space would remain for residents to enjoy and undertake their day-to-day activities. Following the demolition of the existing extension, the proposed structure would extend 4.7m away from the property, 2m further beyond the rear elevation of the adjoining property. With an eaves height of 2.5m close to the boundary, it is considered that there would be no overbearing or dominating impact upon this neighbour's amenity area. Due to the orientation of the properties in this built up area, it is considered that the neighbour would not suffer from a loss of natural light to their property. Due to the alignment of the properties, the proposed first floor infill would have no detrimental impact on this neighbour.On the opposite side, the property is off-set from the boundary with No. 86 and it is considered that the scale and nature of the development would ensure that an acceptable relationship is maintained. Additional windows are proposed within the side elevation of the property, though given that these would face a shared passageway with No. 86 then no overlooking issues would be experienced. Similarly, it is considered that the first floor infill would have no adverse impact upon the amenity of this neighbouring property.It is considered that the proposed development would be in scale and character with the original property, and that there would be no adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the area. Residential amenity for occupants of the property and their neighbours would not be compromised as a result of the development. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The side and rear extensions are proposed to replace the existing single storey rear and side extensions. The proposed single storey side extension would reduce in width and create a separation distance of a minimum of 0.8m from the boundary. It would not be set back from the front elevation but as this would be a continuation of what is existing there would be no adverse effect to the streetscene. The two storey side extension would be set back from the front boundary by 0.5m which is recommended by the Residential Design Guide SPD. The pitched roof would also be set in from the main roof slope and thus would ensure the development is subordinate to the host property.The proposed replacement part single storey rear extension would be the same depth as what is existing, would continue the existing roof form and would use materials to match the existing dwelling. Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The two storey side extension would be proposed to gain a separation distance from the neighbouring boundary with No. 21a Grayham Road. Given the modest width of the proposed development and separation distance it is not likely to adversely affect the amenities of the neighbouring property. Further, all windows to the ground floor side elevation are proposed to be obscure glazed. The single storey rear extension would replace the existing rear conservatory and retain similar dimensions, therefore it would not adversely affect the amenities of the neighbouring properties. Therefore, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
sf

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Three neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed side/rear extension would extend to 3m in depth and extend no further in width than the existing side elevation. The hipped roof would have a height that is within the parameters recommended by the Residential Design SPD 2013. The development would not be viewed from the streetscene, and all materials proposed would be in keeping with the host property.Therefore, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The single storey rear/side extension would extend approx 1.7m further in depth than neighbouring property No. 8 Douglas Road's rear extension. However, due to the existing parapet wall and boundary treatment the proposed extension would not adversely affect the amenities of this neighbouring property. No. 4 Douglas Road would be separated from the proposed development by approx 1.3m, therefore due to its siting would not cause loss of light/sunlight or feeling of overbearing. Two openings are proposed to the side elevation but would offer similar views to what is already existing and therefore would not cause an increase to overlooking for this neighbouring property.Therefore, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
